question: Which of the following is the commonest neuroglia found in the peripheral nervous system?
explanation: Neuroglial cells surround the neurons providing them with support and protection. They play a significant role in phagocytosis and myelin production. Neuroglial cells are of two main types known as microglia and macroglia. Microglia are specialised macrophages found in the central nervous system (CNS) whereas macroglia are found in both CNS and the peripheral nervous system (PNS). Schwann cell s, satellite cells and enteric glial cells are macroglia found in the PNS. Astrocytes, ependymal cells, oligodendrocytes and radial glial cells are macroglia found in the CNS. The most abundant type of macroglia in the PNS is the Schwann cells. However, overall, the most abundant type of macroglia is astrocytes.

question: A 45-year-old woman was diagnosed with an intrinsic brain tumour. Which of the following is the most likely tumour?
explanation: Intrinsic brain tumours include various grades of glioma, astrocytoma, oligodendroglioma, medulloblastoma, lymphoma and ependymoma. Oligodendroglioma is found in 10% of adults and 4% of children with primary brain tumour. The most common form of astrocytoma is gliobastoma multiforme. Extrinsic brain tumours include meningioma, neuroma, epidermoid tumour, glomus jugulare and chordoma.

question: Which of the following brain structures include a dentate nucleus?
explanation: Dentate nucleus is one of the four deep cerebellar nuclei that connect cerebellum to other regions of brain. It is phylogenetically the most recent and lateral nuclei. It is located in deep white matter. Other three deep cerebellar nuclei are called fastigial, globose and emboliform nuclei. The largest deep cerebellar nucleus is dentate nucleus and the smallest is an interposed nucleus which is a combined globose and emboliform nucleus.

question: Astereognosis is the inability to recognise objects by touching and is linked to Brodmann's areas. Which of the following Brodmann's areas are affected in a stereognosis?
explanation: Astereognosia is associated with a lesion in the somatosensory association cortex that is located in Brodmann's areas 5 and 7. Loss of saccadic eye movement and impaired visual search is linked to lesions in the frontal eye fields (Brodmann's area 8) and dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (Brodmann's area 9). Impulsive behaviour and perseveration can be seen as a result of lesions in the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (Brodmann's area 9) and anterior prefrontal cortex (Brodmann's area 10). Visual object agnosia is related to lesions in the secondary visual cortex (Brodmann's area 18), associative visual cortex (Brodmann's area 19) and inferior temporal gyrus (Brodmann's area 20). Auditory agnosia can occur as a result of lesions in the superior temporal gyrus (Brodmann's area 22) and primary auditory cortex (Brodmann's area 42).

question: Which of the following is most likely to be due to a lesion in left Brodmann's areas 39 and 40?
explanation: The lesion in area 6 is associated with agraphia without alexia and those in areas 7 and 40 are associated with Gerstmann's syndrome. Lesions 18 and 19 can cause alexia without agraphia. However, lesions 39 and 40, and the frontal lobe lesion can cause acalculia. The lesion in area 22 gives rise to Wernicke's aphasia.

question: Which of the following about the neuropathology of schizophrenia is correct?

options.B: No reduction in the anteroposterior length of the cerebral hemisphere
options.D: Significant differences found in hippocampal area
options.E: Slight and insignificant reduction in brain mass

explanation: Neuroimaging studies have found that parahippocampal gyrus is smaller in patients with schizophrenia compared with controls. Other structural changes noticed in schizophrenia include reduction in the brain mass, temporal lobe, cerebral volumes and overall brain length. There is ventricular enlargement, particularly involving the temporal horn. There is no significant difference in the hippocampal area.

question: Which of the following are characteristic changes seen in patients with the punch-drunk syndrome?
explanation: Punch-drunk syndrome, also known as boxer's dementia or dementia pugilistica, occurs in professional boxers who are subjected to repeated blows, resulting in concussions. It is a neurodegenerative disease in which individuals present with symptoms suggestive of dementia, parkinsonism, memory loss, and gait and speech problems. On macroscopic examination of the postmortem brain there is evidence of perforation of the septum pellucidum, cerebral atrophy, ventricular enlargement, thinning of the corpus callosum, brain tissue scarring and hydrocephalus. On microscopic examination there is evidence of neuronal loss, collections of senile plaques and neurofibrillary tangles.

question: A 72-year-old man was diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease. Which of the following brain regions sustain most atrophy change?
explanation: Macroscopic changes in Alzheimer's disease include global brain atrophy, ventricular brain enlargement and widening of the sulci. In this disease, atrophy is most significant in the frontal and temporal lobes of the brain.

question: A 42-year-old man was diagnosed with Pick's disease. Which of the following pathological features is most likely to be found?

options.D: Symmetrical atrophy of the anterior temporal lobes

explanation: Pick's disease is a rare neurodegenerative disorder. In this disorder there is asymmetrical atrophy of the frontal and temporal lobes with sparing of the occipital and parietal lobes. The cerebral atrophy is so severe that some of the gyri are extremely thin, which is also known as knife blade gyri.

question: Which of the following is the characteristic pathological feature of Creutzfeldt–Jakob disease?
explanation: Creutzfeldt–Jakob disease (CJD) is a fatal degenerative brain disease. CJD is transmitted by infection with a prion, which is a protein in misfolded form. There are several types of CJD such as sporadic, variant, familial and iatrogenic types. In CJD there is selective cerebellar atrophy, generalised cerebral atrophy and ventricular enlargement.

question: Which of the following regulates growth hormone from the anterior pituitary gland?

options.A: Combined growth hormone-releasing hormone (GHRH) and somatostatins

explanation: Growth hormone is secreted by somatotrophic cells which are located within the anterior pituitary gland. It is under the stimulatory effect of growth hormone-releasing factor (GHRH or somatocrinin) and the inhibitory effect of somatostatins, both of which are released from neurosecretory cells in the hypothalamus.

question: Which of the following is a ligand-gated channel?
explanation: The ion channels are classified into families on the basis of genetic sequence, homology and possibly pore lining α-sub unit type. The main families are transmembrane agents (6 TM, 4/8 TM, 2 TM), inotropic glutamate receptors, nicotinic-related receptors, intracellular calcium ion channels and chloride ion channels. Glutamate receptor is a ligand-gated ion channel.

question: Each electroencephalogram (EEG) electrode placement allows it to preferentially record over a cortical surface area. What is the approximate area covered by an EEG electrode?
explanation: International 10–20 system is a recognised system that describes the electrode placement on the scalp in an electroencephalogram (EEG) investigation. In this system, the scalp is divided into a grid that helps in compensating for the different head size in different patients. Each electrode records approximately 6 cm² of the cortical area.

question: Which of the following statements about the sinusoidal waveform EEG is correct?

options.A: Both extracellular and intracellular components are recorded on the EEG
options.B: The waveform generated by direct excitatory and inhibitory interaction of neighbouring cortical cell columns
options.C: The waveform is an indirect consequence of the additive effect of groups of cortical pyramidal neurons
options.E: There is variations in both the strength and the density of the current loops

explanation: Waveforms on an EEG can be monomorphic, polymorphic, sinusoidal or transient. The variations in both strength and density of the current loops lead to development of the characteristic sinusoidal waveform.

question: Which of the following describes cortisol accurately?

options.B: Elevated serum concentration in the morning

explanation: Cortisol has a negative feedback effect on the hypothalamus, hippocampus and pituitary gland. It is a glucocorticoid steroid hormone that is secreted by zona fasciculata found in the adrenal cortex.

question: Which of the following is a monoamine neurotransmitter?
explanation: A monoamine neurotransmitter can be both a neurotransmitter and a neuromodulator. Aromatic amino acids such as phenylalanince, tryptophan, thyroid hormones and tyrosine produce monoamine neurotransmitters.

question: Which of the following is the main effector of dopaminergic receptors?
explanation: The dopamine receptors are coupled to G-proteins. The main effectors of dopamine receptors are D1 which increases adenylyl cyclase, D2 which decreases adenylyl cyclase, D3 which decreases adenylyl cyclase, D4 which decreases adenylyl cyclase and D5 which increases adenylyl cyclase.

question: Which of the following peptide secretions from neurons is released directly into the blood?
explanation: A neurohormone is a peptide secretion from neuroendocrine cells. It is released directly into the blood and reaches the systemic circulation, e.g. corticotrophin-releasing hormone.

question: Which of the following is consistent with N-methyl-d-aspartate receptors?
explanation: N-Methyl- d-aspartate (NMDA) is a type of glutamate receptor, and an excitatory amino acid neurotransmitter.

question: A 67-year-old man underwent MRI recently. The scan showed focal atrophy of the caudate nucleus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: Focal atrophy of the caudate nucleus is often seen on CT or MRI in Huntington's disease.

question: In which of the following conditions will MRI investigation show evidence of plaques in well over 90% of cases?
explanation: Neuroimaging, mainly MRI, is helpful in diagnosis and follow-up of patients with multiple sclerosis.

question: Which of the following imaging modalities involves the BOLD technique?
explanation: A technique that is dependent on the blood oxygenation level is used in functional MRI (fMRI) to detect images that are based on cerebral blood flow and regional activity.

question: Which of the following is used in clinical practice to measure glutamate, urea and ammonia?
explanation: Magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS) is used to measure metabolic changes in conditions such as stroke, brain tumours, Alzheimer's dementia and other neurological illnesses.

question: What is the mechanism of action of lofexidine?
explanation: Opioids inhibit noradrenaline release, and discontinuation of opioids causes a rebound release of noradrenaline. Lofexidine, an α2-adrenoceptor agonist, acts by reducing the noradrenergic storm that follows discontinuation of opioids.

question: Which of the following drugs is a partial m agonist?
explanation: Buprenorphine is a partial m agonist opioid, used for analgesia and treatment of opioid dependence.

question: Which of the following statements applies to the pharmacokinetic properties of most psychotropic drugs?

options.A: Most of them are affected by second-pass metabolism
options.B: Most of them are minimally bound to proteins in the plasma
options.C: They are poorly absorbed from the gut
options.D: They are poorly ionised at a physiological pH
options.E: They pass easily from plasma to the brain because they are hydrophilic

explanation: Ionisation of drugs is largely dependent on the pH of the solution. It affects the absorption, distribution and elimination of drugs in the body. Antipsychotics are not highly ionised at physiological pH. In general, most psychotropic drugs are easily absorbed from the gut and they pass from the plasma to the brain due to their lipophilic property. Most of them are metabolised in the liver and are affected by first-pass metabolism. They are largely bound to proteins in the plasma, but only plasma-free fractions are pharmacologically active.

question: Which of the following statements about the effects of ageing on pharmacokinetics is correct?

options.A: The receptor sensitivity is not affected
options.B: The unbound proportion of albumin-bound drugs decreases
options.C: The rate of absorption is increased
options.D: The total amount of drug absorbed is reduced
options.E: The volume of distribution increases for lipid-soluble drugs

explanation: Total body water and lean body mass decrease in old age, whereas total body fat increases. This leads to an increase in volume of distribution (Vd) for lipid-soluble drugs but a decreased Vd for water-soluble drugs. Receptor sensitivity may increase in old age, leading to increased effects of the drugs. Due to delayed gastric emptying and slow motility, absorption is usually slowed down but just as complete. The albumin level decreases so the proportion of free or unbound drug increases. Half-lives are usually prolonged.

question: Which of the following antipsychotics is not a substrate for cytochrome P450CYP450-2D6?
explanation: This is metabolised by the cytochrome P450 CYP450-2D6 into its active metabolite, paliperidone. Therefore, paliperidone itself is not a substrate for this enzyme. All the other antipsychotics mentioned in the question are metabolised by this enzyme. Therefore, in theory, their dose should be reduced when a CYP450-2D6 inhibitor (e.g. fluoxetine, paroxetine, duloxetine) is administered concomitantly. In the case of risperidone, it increases the risk of extrapyramidal side effects. Paliperidone injection is indicated for maintenance in patients with schizophrenia who had previously responded to risperidone or paliperidone tablets.

question: Carbamazepine is not available as an intravenous injection. What is the most likely reason?

options.A: It can cause severe allergic reaction
options.C: It is highly insoluble in water
options.D: It is highly toxic as an intravenous preparation
options.E: It rapidly distributes into all the tissues

explanation: Carbamazepine is poorly soluble in water and most other liquids. Hence, it has been difficult to develop an intravenous formulation. However, recently a University of Minnesota group has developed intravenous carbamazepine using cyclodextrins. A study published in 2009 suggested that the intravenous formulation was safe, although it will be long before it is available for use in patients. Carbamazepine dissolves rapidly into the tissues with 70–80% plasma bound. It has a half-life of 26 hours (18–54 hours) after the first dose.

question: A 32-year-old man had epilepsy. He was treated with carbamazepine 200 mg twice a day. His last serum carbamazepine levels were within normal limits. He was brought to the emergency department after a seizure and his carbamazepine levels were noticed to be low. He had been taking medication regularly, did not use illicit drugs or alcohol and was not on any other medication. What is the most likely explanation?

options.A: Carbamazepine could be absorbed less in the intestine
options.D: Renal excretion of carbamazepine is increased
options.E: There is no reason for his blood levels to be low

explanation: Carbamazepine is an enzyme inducer and can induce its own metabolism. The half-life of carbamazepine after a single dose is 26 hours (18–54 hours). After repeated use it can be decreased to 5–26 hours.

question: Which of the following explains varenicline's mechanism of action?
explanation: Varenicline is a partial agonist of nicotine acetylcholine receptor. It is used in people who wish to stop smoking. By its partial agonist activity on the α4β2-subtype of nicotine receptor, it helps in reducing the craving and withdrawal symptoms of smoking. Furthermore, it can reduce the positive effects of smoking, thereby helping a smoker to quit.

question: Which of the following sets of benzodiazepines is correctly arranged in decreasing order of potency?
explanation: Table 1.1 describes the equivalent dose of commonly used benzodiazepines. The lower the equivalent dose, the higher the potency of the drug.

question: Which of the following is the most potent inhibitor of CYP450-2D6?
explanation: CYP450-2D6 enzyme metabolises various antidepressants including tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs), duloxetine and selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs). It also converts venlafaxine into its active metabolite, desvenlafaxine. Paroxetine, duloxetine and fluoxetine are its potent inhibitors whereas other SSRIs, reboxetine and bupropion are among its weak inhibitors. Answers: MCQs 29 Concomitant administration of TCAs and SSRIs may require a dose reduction of TCAs. Concomitant administration of CYP450-2D6 inhibitors can also interfere with the analgesic effect of codeine.

question: Which of the following statements explains the mechanism of action of sildenafil?

options.A: By inducing the enzyme phosphodiesterase V, it raises the levels of cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP)
options.B: By inducing the enzyme phosphodiesterase V, it reduces the levels of cGMP
options.C: By inhibiting the enzyme phosphodiesterase V, it raises the levels of cGMP
options.D: By inhibiting the enzyme phosphodiesterase V, it reduces the levels of cGMP
options.E: By inhibiting the enzyme phosphodiesterase V, it has no effect on the levels of cGMP

explanation: Normally cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP) causes smooth muscle relaxation, resulting in a physiological erection. The cGMP is broken down in the penis by phosphodiesterase-V enzyme. Sildenafil inhibits the enzyme, so helping the levels of cGMP to build up in the penis, leading to an erection. A desire to have sex is essential for sildenafil to work, meaning that it will not work during sleep.

question: Which of the following explains the mechanism of action of zopiclone?

options.A: Binding to g-aminobutyric acid type A (GABA-A) and GABA-B receptors
options.B: Non-selective binding to a-subunits of GABA-A receptors
options.C: Selective binding to a1-subunit of GABA-A receptors
options.D: Selective binding to the g subunit of GABA-C receptors
options.E: Selective binding to the Z subunit of GABA-A receptors

explanation: There are three types of g-aminobutyric acid (GABA) receptors: GABA-A, GABA-B and GABA-C. GABA-A receptors have different subtypes depending on the subunits: α (1–6), β (1–3), γ (1–3), δ, ε, π, Ω and ρ (1–3). Zopiclone, eszopiclone and benzodiazepines bind to α1, α2, α3 and α5 subunits of GABA-A receptors. Alpha-1 subtype is critical for sedation and is also linked to daytime sedation, anticonvulsant action and amnesia. Zaleplon and zolpidem are selective to the α1-subtype and so have less risk of tolerance and dependence.

question: A 34-year-old woman had depression. She was on fluoxetine 60 mg once a day. Her clinician reduced the dose to 40 mg a day and added mirtazapine 15 mg once a day. Next day, she developed fever, tachycardia, muscle twitches and confusion. Which of the following can explain this reaction?
explanation: Pharmacodynamics is the study of the biochemical and physiological effects of the drug on the body. Pharmacodynamic interaction happens when drugs that have same or opposing action are given together. These drugs may alter the sensitivity or response of the body to the drugs. There are some reports of serotonin syndrome due to an interaction between mirtazapine and fluoxetine when co-administered.

question: Which of the following statements about myristoylated alanine-rich C kinase substrate (MARCKS) is correct?

options.A: MARCKS is a protein kinase substrate
options.B: MARCKS is a substrate of carbamazepine
options.C: MARCKS is implicated in the treatment of epilepsy
options.D: MARCKS is implicated in the treatment of pain
options.E: There is significant down-regulation of MARCKS with repeated use of carbamazepine

explanation: This is an abbreviation for myristoylated alanine-rich C kinase substrate (MARCKS) protein. Recent studies show that the mood-stabilising effect of mood stabilisers are attributed to the effect of medication on MARCKS. It has been noticed that with use of sodium valproate and lithium there is a significant down-regulation of MARCKS expression. Carbamazepine lacks this effect, indicating that the mechanism of mood stabilisation of carbamazepine is different to that of lithium or sodium valproate.

question: Which of the following anti-dementia drugs has the longest half-life?
explanation: This has a half-life of 70 hours. Galantamine has a half-life of 7–8 hours. Rivastigmine has a half-life of 1.5 hours. Tacrine has a half-life of 24–36 hours. Memantine has a half-life of 60–100 hours.

question: Which of the following adverse effects of clozapine is independent of dose?
explanation: This is an idiosyncratic reaction that is difficult to predict. It is dose independent. About 2.7% of patients treated with clozapine develop neutropenia, whereas approximately 0.8% will develop agranulocytosis. Immune-mediated and direct cytotoxic effects can explain this side effect. The treatment for agranulocytosis is to stop clozapine. Another example of an idiosyncratic side effect of an antipsychotic medication is neuroleptic malignant syndrome.

question: Which of the following is a risk factor for QTc prolongation on an ECG and arrhythmia?
explanation: Normal limits for QTc are <440 ms for men and <470 ms for women. There is a strong evidence that a QTc interval >500 ms is associated with a risk of arrhythmia. Hypokalaemia, hypomagnesaemia, hypocalcaemia, long QT syndrome, bradycardia, ischaemic heart disease, myocarditis, myocardial infarction, left ventricular hypertrophy, extreme physical exertion, stress or shock, anorexia nervosa, extremes of age (children and elderly people) and female gender are risk factors for QTc prolongation and arrhythmia.

question: A 43-year-old man with chronic schizophrenia is being treated with depot antipsychotic injections. He is seen in the outpatient clinic because he has had motor side effects. Which of the following is the most appropriate scale for a baseline assessment and subsequent follow-up?
explanation: The Simpson–Angus scale is widely used in clinical trials of antipsychotic drugs to assess extrapyramidal symptoms. It is relatively easy to administer in a clinical setting. The brief psychiatric rating scale is used to rate psychiatric symptoms rather than motor side effects. The Bush Francis scale is used to rate catatonic features. The Barnes' akathisia rating scale is used to assess akathisia. The unified Parkinson's disease rating scale is used to assess Parkinson's disease, not drug-induced parkinsonism.

question: Which of the following is the most appropriate drug to treat poststroke depression?
explanation: Depression is seen in about 30–40% of patients who survive a stroke. Mirtazapine, nortriptyline, fluoxetine, escitalopram and sertraline are recommended for prophylaxis. SSRIs, nortriptyline and mirtazapine are recommended to treat post-stroke depression. If a patient is prescribed warfarin, citalopram is the recommended SSRI due to fewer drug interactions. When using SSRI in an anticoagulated or aspirin-treated patient, use of a proton pump inhibitor should be considered for gastric protection.

question: Which of the following drugs is currently licensed in the UK for treatment of generalised anxiety disorder?
explanation: Pregabalin is also licensed for the treatment of generalised anxiety disorder. In addition gabapentin and pregabalin are licensed for neuropathic pain and indicated in conditions such as fibromyalgia. Lamotrigine is also licensed for prophylaxis of bipolar depression. Vigabatrin and tiagabine are usually used as an adjunct treatment for epilepsy.

question: A 32-year-old woman with a past history of three manic episodes and one inpatient admission is stabilised on haloperidol and lithium. The last episode occurred 2 years ago. She has recently discovered that she is 6 weeks pregnant. What is the best course of action?

options.A: Continue both the drugs without any change
options.B: Continue haloperidol and lithium in reduced dosages
options.C: Stop both the drugs and monitor patient closely
options.E: Stop lithium and switch haloperidol to chlorpromazine

explanation: Lithium is best avoided in the first trimester because of its teratogenic potential. Antipsychotics (preferably first generation, but now evidence is building up for second-generation antipsychotics) should be used as mood stabilisers in pregnancy, if required. This patient is at high risk of relapse if the medications are stopped. There is no need to switch to chlorpromazine. Switching unnecessarily is associated with a risk of relapse.

question: Who established that clozapine is effective in treating treatment-resistant schizophrenia?
explanation: Table 1.2 describes the contribution of key people in psychiatry. Answers: MCQs 31 Table 1.2 Famous people and their contribution to psychiatry Name Contribution John Cade Discovered mood-stabiliser effects of lithium carbonate John Kane In 1988, John Kane and colleagues conducted a double-blind study comparing the efficacy of chlorpromazine and clozapine/clozaril in treatment-resistant schizophrenia and established that clozapine was clearly superior to chlorpromazine Jean Delay and Pierre Deniker Established antipsychotic effect of the first antipsychotic, chlorpromazine, in the 1950s Max Fink Best known for his work on electroconvulsive therapy Nancy Andreasen Known figure in use of neuroimaging in the study of schizophrenia.

question: Which of the following statements about disulfiram is correct?

options.B: It is a reversible inhibitor of the enzyme
options.C: It should be used at least 12 hours after the last alcohol ingestion
options.D: Its use with alcohol can cause hypotension
options.E: Its use with alcohol can lead to decreased levels of acetaldehyde in the blood

explanation: Alcohol is metabolised by alcohol dehydrogenase, which is further metabolised by aldehyde dehydrogenase. Disulfiram irreversibly inhibits aldehyde dehydrogenase, leading to accumulation of aldehyde in the system, producing symptoms such as flushing, nausea, vomiting and hypotension. It should be used after at least 24 hours of the last alcohol ingestion to avoid any possible disulfiram and alcohol reaction.

question: A 44-year-old man was admitted for alcohol detoxification. He has alcoholic cirrhosis of the liver and his blood investigations showed that his liver enzymes were raised. Which of the following drugs is most appropriate for detoxification?
explanation: Longer-acting benzodiazepines are likely to be accumulated in the body if liver functions are impaired. It may lead to benzodiazepine toxicity. Therefore, shorter-acting benzodiazepines are preferred such as oxazepam (lorazepam). Diazepam and chlordiazepoxide are drugs of choice for detoxification in normal liver functions. Carbamazepine is used for alcohol detoxification in some countries, but in the presence of liver damage, its use is not recommended. Clonazepam is a longer-acting benzodiazepine.

question: In which of the following stages of mitosis does the division of cytoplasm start?
explanation: Mitosis and meiosis are two forms of cell division that occur in eukaryotes. Many of the somatic cells go through cell division via the process of mitosis, which is a form of nuclear division. Meiosis is a special form of cell division for sexual reproduction. Mitosis consists of the following stages: 1. Interphase: before a cell enters into mitosis it goes into a growth period called interphase. 2. Prophase: it is a stage in which chromatin condenses into chromosomes.3. Metaphase: it is a stage in which chromosomes get aligned on metaphase plate.4. Anaphase: in this stage paired chromosomes separate and move to the opposite ends of the cell. 5. Telophase: it is in this stage that division of the cytoplasm begins.

question: Which genetic material is most suitable for postmortem studies of gene expression?
explanation: Postmortem examination for gene expression studies are challenging due to problems with variability in intactness of RNA and biological variants. Intact RNA is essential for these studies to be carried out appropriately. Several studies have concluded that mRNA is stable in postmortem human brain and hence can be used for gene expression. Stability of RNA in postmortem tissue differs with the tissue type and also the tissue storage conditions.

question: Which of the following studies is appropriate to answer the question: 'What are the relative contributions of genes and environment?'
explanation: There has always been a debate about the role of nature and nurture in human development. Twin and adoption studies are the methods of choice for finding out relative contribution of both gene and environment on development. Adoption studies largely consider the impact of environment on the development of a child who has been adopted into a family. Heritability is described as what proportion of observed trait in individuals is due to genetic differences. It is mainly studied by conduction family and twin studies. A family study is conducted basically to answer the question: 'Is the phenotype familial?' Linkage analysis answers the question, 'Where the genes located?' Association analysis helps to find out, 'what the responsible genes are.'

question: What is the production of new copies of RNA from DNA called?
explanation: It is the first step of gene expression in which information from the DNA molecule is transcribed onto an RNA transcript. This process takes place in the nucleus of the cell and consists of five steps: preinitiation, initiation, promoter clearance, elongation and termination. Translation is the process of making proteins from the RNA molecule and takes place in the cytoplasm with the help of ribosomes. Replication, as the name suggests, is a process in which the DNA or genetic material produces a duplicate copy of itself. Modification is a change in phenotype, which is influenced by environmental factors and is not a heritable trait.

question: Which of the following statements about heritability in psychiatric genetics is correct?

options.A: It is measured by the disconcordance rate among twin pairs
options.B: It is a ratio of genetic variance to phenotypic variance
options.C: It is a ratio of phenotypic variance to genetic variance
options.D: It is the proportion of proband twins who have an affected co-twin
options.E: It is the proportion of twin pairs when both of them are affected with the disorder

explanation: Heritability is measured by concordance rate among twin pairs. It is ratio of genetic variance to phenotypic variance (h2 = Vg/Vp), where h2 is heritability and Vg is genetic variance and Vp is the phenotypic variance. A heritability of 1 will indicate that all the phenotypic variability is due to genetic variance.

question: In the example, 'two relatives from same family sharing a common disorder have two alleles in common; one is at LOCI-1 and the other at LOC-2. Co-inheritance of these two alleles along with the disorder in the family tree suggests that some unobserved risk gene for the disorder is present near the loci'. What principle is applied in this case?
explanation: Genetic linkage is described as investigating the co-segregation of the disease and a set of genetic markers while studying disease in families. The aim of linkage analysis is to determine the location of the gene(s) on a chromosome for a trait of interest, e.g. a common disease.

question: Which of the following methods is used to determine whether a particular gene variant directly affects the risk for the disorder?
explanation: In linkage analysis, random DNA markers (consisting of DNA polymorphism) are used as proxies for any nearby risk genes. However, to determine if a particular or specific gene variant is directly affecting the risk for the disorder, or is very tightly linked to such a gene, the most appropriate method is genetic association analysis.

question: Which of the following is correct if very tight linkage occurs between genetic markers in a haplotype?

options.A: Logarithm of odd score will be 3 or 3+
options.B: Markers will not undergo recombination and will be inherited together
options.C: Markers will not undergo recombination and will not be inherited separately
options.D: Markers will undergo recombination and will be inherited together
options.E: Markers will undergo recombination and will not be inherited separately

explanation: Genes that are tightly located near each other on a chromosome tend to be inherited together on meiosis during gene expression.

question: What is the main difference between association studies and linkage studies?

options.A: For association studies, the DNA marker has to be in the disease gene itself
options.B: For linkage studies, the DNA marker has to be very tightly linked to the disease gene
options.C: Linkage analysis has demonstrated strong links between the human leukocyte antigen system and several diseases
options.D: Mutation analysis of polymorphisms is done by linkage analysis
options.E: Association analysis can be used to 'scan the genome'

explanation: Genetic association studies are used to find out if there is a correlation between a disease and genetic variation.

question: Which of the following statements about gene expression is correct?

options.A: Genetic information flows from RNA to DNA to polypeptides
options.B: Most genes encode peptides and are transcribed by RNA polymerase 2
options.C: RNA splicing, capping and polyadenylation are pretranscriptional
options.D: Tryptophan is specified by several codons

explanation: Expression of genetic information is unidirectional from DNA to RNA to polypeptides, and involves transcription which is in 5´-3´ orientation.

question: What is the commonest cause of inherited learning disability?
explanation: This syndrome is the second most common specific cause of learning disability after Down's syndrome, although it is the most common inherited cause for learning disability.

question: Which of the following perturbations is most convincingly linked with aggregates in families in panic disorder of adults?
explanation: Perturbation or disturbance in respiration has been most convincingly linked to panic disorder in adults.

question: In a third of children with autism, there is an increased peripheral level of a neurotransmitter. Which of the following neurotransmitters is implicated?
explanation: One of the most robust findings in autism research has been an increased level of peripheral serotonin in a third of children with autism.

question: What is the percentage ratio genetic liability: depression by direct effect or indirect effect respectively?
explanation: In a landmark study by Kendler and colleagues on twins, the percentage ratio of direct:indirect effects of genetic liability to depression are 60:40 respectively.

question: The concordance rate of bulimia nervosa in dizygotic twins is 30%. What is the likely concordance rate in monozygotic twins?
explanation: Numerous studies in family, twin and adopted children have identified the role of genetics and heritability in eating disorders.

question: Which of the following terms describes the probability of manifestation of a disorder given a particular genotype?
explanation: The probability of expression of an allele when present in the genotype is termed 'penetrance'.

question: Which of the following personality traits is an endophenotype for suicide behaviour?
explanation: Suicidal behaviour can have a genetic predisposition and certain candidate endophenotypes can influence suicide risk.

question: Which of the following is the neurochemical endophenotype in suicidal behaviour?
explanation: Changes in CSF 5-HIAA levels have been associated with impulsive suicide attempts.

question: Which of the following electroencephalogram (EEG) changes have been used as an endophenotype in linkage studies for alcohol dependence?
explanation: Two kinds of EEG activities are used as endophenotypes in alcohol dependence.

question: Which of the following factors about the family history of alcoholism is correct?

options.A: Behavioural disturbances in childhood are associated with higher rates of alcoholism
options.B: Children of alcoholics are less likely to be exposed to high-risk environments
options.C: Female alcoholics with a family history of alcoholism have poorer outcomes
options.D: Late onset of alcoholism is associated with increased rates of alcoholism in the family
options.E: The rates of familial alcoholism are independent of socioeconomic status

explanation: Conduct disorder and behavioural disturbances in childhood lead to higher rates of alcoholism.

question: Which of the following statements is one of the results of the Irish affected sibling pair study?

options.B: Chromosomal variations in chromosome 14 are strongly related to alcoholism
options.C: Chromosomal variations in chromosome 3 are strongly related to alcoholism
options.D: Chromosomal variations in chromosome 4 are strongly related to alcoholism
options.E: Chromosomal variations in chromosome 21 are strongly related to alcoholism

explanation: A study in Irish affected sibling pairs of alcohol dependence is a linkage study analysing the genetic aspects of alcohol misuse.

question: In which of the following conditions is the effect of genetic predisposition strongest?
explanation: The strongest effect for genetic predisposition is seen in autism and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).

question: Which of the following transcription factors is implicated in anxiety, alcohol abuse and substance dependence?
explanation: CREB is an abbreviation for cAMP-response element-binding protein. It is a transcription factor implicated in wide range of psychiatric conditions.

question: Which of the following statements about cannabis-induced psychosis is correct?

options.A: Cannabis misuse causing psychosis is an intoxication phenomenon
options.B: Cannabis misuse causing psychosis is reversible in all individuals
options.C: If a boy misuses cannabis from 11 years of age and stops in a year, the chances of developing psychosis are the same as in the general population
options.D: Individuals with the COMT (catechol-O-methyl transferase) gene met/met allele are at high risk of developing cannabis-induced psychosis
options.E: Individuals with the COMT gene val/val allele are at high risk of developing cannabis-induced psychosis

explanation: Allelic variation in the COMT gene is associated with an increased incidence of psychosis related to cannabis misuse.

question: What does the term 'envirome' mean?

options.A: Internal as well as external environment of the individual
options.B: The environmental factors that predispose as well trigger psychiatric disorders
options.C: The immediate environment of an individual in which he or she lives
options.D: The internal environment of the individual that leads to a psychiatric disorder
options.E: The work and household environment of an individual that are stressful and lead to a psychiatric disorder

explanation: The term 'envirome' refers to the totality of equivalent environmental influences and includes predisposing factors such as intrauterine exposure to radiation, teratogens, family income and neighbourhoods.

question: Abnormalities of chromosomes can lead to a psychosis that is similar to schizophrenia. Which of the following chromosomes is implicated in psychosis?
explanation: Deletions on the end of chromosome 22 cause a wide range of physical as well as mental health abnormalities.

question: What does the term 'ontogenic niche' mean?

options.A: The ecological and social settings that an individual shares with parents
options.B: The ecological and social settings that an individual shares with peers
options.C: The ecological environment in which a person lives that modifies the genes
options.D: The internal environment of an individual that modifies the genes
options.E: The social environment in which a person lives that modifies the genes

explanation: An ontogenetic niche means that an organism shares not only genes but also the ecological and social environment with its parents.

question: You conducted a family study of patients with recurrent depressive disorder. Your findings showed that there was an increased risk of developing depression in parents' siblings and offsprings as probands, whereas second- and third-degree relatives do not have the increased risk. What does this mean?

options.A: Environmental factors play a more important role in the development of depression than genetic factors
options.B: Genetic factors play a more important role in the development of depression than environment
options.C: There is no role for environmental factors in the development of depression
options.D: There is no role for genetic factors in the development of depression
options.E: This finding does not give any conclusive evidence as to whether genetic or environmental factors play a major role in the development of depression

explanation: When family studies into first-degree relatives conclude that there is increased incidence of illness in first-degree relatives, all it tells us is that the illness is familial. This could be due to genetic or shared environmental factors.

question: What is the 12-month prevalence of mental disorders in Europe?
explanation: European study of epidemiology of mental disorders (ESEMED) is a multicentric study conducted in six European countries such as Belgium, France, Netherlands, Spain, Italy and Germany. This study is a part of WHO mental health survey initiative. According to ESEMED, the life time prevalence of mental disorders in Europe is 1 in 4 whereas the prevalence of mental disorder in the past 1 year (12-month prevalence) is 1 in 10.

question: According to a 10-year follow-up study of patients with borderline personality disorder, what is the median time to remission of the abandonment symptom?
explanation: The study of Zanarini et al. (2007) noted two main findings: out of the 24 symptoms studied over a 10-year period < 15% were exhibited; the other 12 symptoms declined less substantially with about 20–40% still exhibiting at the end of the 10-year period.

question: What is the reported prevalence of late-onset paraphrenia among elderly people in the community?
explanation: The reported prevalence of elderly people in the community with paraphrenia is 0.1–4%. According to Targun and Abbott (1999), the prevalence is 0.2–4.7%. Hence, one can safely assume a prevalence of 1–5% as the right answer in this case.

question: What is the prevalence of late-onset paraphrenia in elderly people in a psychiatric hospital population?
explanation: Approximately 10% of the elderly population admitted to a psychiatric ward have paraphrenia. Studies suggest that a wide range, from 10% to 63%, of the elderly population in nursing homes have psychotic symptoms.

question: If the prevalence of dementia is to be reduced by 50%, by how many years should the onset of dementia need to be delayed?
explanation: If the onset of dementia is delayed by 5 years, the prevalence can be reduced by 50%. A delay of 6 months can also reduce prevalence by 6%. This delay can be achieved by successful risk reduction strategies.

question: Elimination of depression from the elderly population can lead to a reduction in the number of new cases over a period of 7 years. What is the mean reduction expected?
explanation: Ritchie et al (2010) concluded that elimination of depression from the elderly population can lead to a mean reduction of 10.3% in new cases of dementia over a period of 7 years. In addition, if depression and diabetes are eliminated from the elderly population and there is an increase in fruit and vegetable consumption, there can be a mean reduction of 20.7% in new cases of dementia.

question: With regard to problem behaviour in patients with learning disability, which of the following is correct?

options.B: Mainly one type of problem behaviour found

explanation: Problem behaviours in patients with learning disability are commoner in males in the age group 15–34 years. The prevalence is about 10–15%. The prevalence increases with an increase in the severity of the learning difficulty.

question: Which of the following statements about alcohol-related dementia is correct?

options.A: Early onset is associated with a poor prognosis
options.B: It accounts for 15% of the dementia population
options.C: It occurs more in areas of high socioeconomic status
options.D: It presents most commonly at the age of 40–50 years
options.E: The prevalence of Wernicke's aphasia/Korsakoff's syndrome is on the decrease

explanation: Alcohol is responsible for 10% of the dementia population. It may contribute to 21–24% of cognitive impairment in mid-adulthood. The frequency of alcohol-related dementia is higher in socioeconomically deprived areas and most of the cases present at age 50–60 years. The earlier the onset of alcohol-related dementia the poorer the prognosis.

question: Which one of the following is not a predictor of course and outcome in schizophrenia?

options.A: Characteristics of the onset of the illness
options.B: Features of initial clinical state and treatment response
options.C: First rank symptoms at the baseline
options.D: History of past psychotic episodes and treatment

explanation: Possible predictors of course and outcome in schizophrenia are sociodemographic status, initial clinical state, treatment response, history of past psychotic episodes and treatment, premorbid personality, functioning, type of the onset, family history of psychiatric disorders, variables of brain morphology and neurocognition. Good prognosis is indicated in acute onset, prominent affective features, no family history, paranoid subtype, good premorbid adjustment and older age of onset.

question: Which of the following statements about a cross-sectional study is correct?

options.B: It can explore multiple outcomes and exposures
options.D: It is suitable for rare conditions
options.E: It takes a long time to complete

explanation: Cross-sectional studies are simplest of all individual-level studies. They are cheaper and quicker than other studies and can explore multiple outcomes and exposures at the same time. They are used to quantify the prevalence of the disease in question. It allows for hypothesis generation based on the aetiology.

question: Which of the following statements is a characteristic feature of a qualitative study?

options.B: It is based on a survey
options.D: It is useful to generate a hypothesis
options.E: The sampling method used is statistical

explanation: A qualitative study helps in generating a hypothesis. This study is concerned with an individual's personal meanings, experiences, feelings, values and other types of opinions.

question: The suicide rate has increased worldwide in the last 45 years. Which of the following reflects the increased rate?
explanation: According to the WHO, suicide rates have increased by 60% in the last 45 years. The global mortality rate is 16 per 100,000 or one death every 40 seconds.

question: In which age group was the suicide rate highest by sex and age in the UK from 2000 to 2009?
explanation: In the UK from 2000 to 2009, the suicide rate was found to be highest among males aged 15–44 years.

question: What is the cross-sectional observation of the number of individuals with a disease in a specified population called?
explanation: Point prevalence is the number of individuals with the disease in a population at a particular point in time. It is expressed as a proportion.

question: A disease under study has a high prevalence. What is the most likely possibility?

options.A: High incidence, short duration of disease
options.B: High incidence, long duration of disease
options.C: Low incidence, short duration of disease
options.D: Low incidence, long duration of disease
options.E: Low incidence due to rare disease

explanation: Prevalence is defined as a proportion of the product of the incidence rate and average duration of a disease. Prevalence = Incidence × Duration of illness. Hence, prevalence can be high even if incidence is low due to a long duration of illness.

question: What is the number of new cases of a disease over a period of time out of the total population at risk called?
explanation: Cumulative incidence or incidence risk is the number of new cases of a disease over a period of time out of the total population at risk.

question: What does comparing observed deaths to expected deaths signify?
explanation: The number of deaths observed divided by number of expected deaths multiplied by 100 gives the standardised mortality rate (SMR). An SMR of 100 signifies that the standard population and population under study have the same mortality rate.

question: Which of the following rating scales is a self-rating scale to measure symptom severity and change in a mental illness?
explanation: Rating scales used in psychiatry can be self-administered, semi-structured or clinician administered. Beck's depression inventory and Zung's self-rating depression scale are self-administered.

question: Which of the following statements about the Y-BOCS is correct?

options.C: It is useful to assess obsessions
options.D: It is useful to monitor the response to treatment
options.E: It is used only in research settings

explanation: The Yale–Brown obsessive compulsive scale (Y-BOCS) gives a measure of distress and not anxiety. It is not a diagnostic tool and is used only to assess the severity of the obsessive–compulsive disorder.

question: What is the tendency of a rater to overestimate a patient's response based on prior assumptions called?
explanation: This effect is a cognitive bias in which there is a tendency to overestimate a response by a rater based on previous impressions, assumptions and judgements.

question: What is the denominator in maternal mortality rate?

options.E: All live births + still births + perinatal deaths

explanation: The maternal mortality rate is the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births in the same time period.

question: Which of the following statements about memory is correct?

options.A: Encoding is related to concepts of memory storage
options.B: Long-term memory is also known as working memory
options.D: Transfer of memory to long-term memory begins 30 minutes after information enters short-term memory
options.E: Unless rehearsed, storage in short-term memory is limited to 30 seconds

explanation: Unless rehearsed, storage in short-term memory is limited to no more than 30 seconds, with a capacity of around seven units.

question: Which of the following statements about neurocognition in schizophrenia is correct?

options.A: Attention-processing speed is impaired more than the executive function domain
options.B: Deterioration in IQ is more rapid after the first episode of schizophrenia than the subsequent episodes
options.C: Deficits in motor skills are more pronounced than in the verbal memory domain
options.D: Illness chronicity accounts for most cognitive impairments in schizophrenia
options.E: Neurocognitive impairments usually begin after the first episode of schizophrenia

explanation: Neurocognitive impairments are reliably and broadly present in the first episode of schizophrenia.

question: Which of the following statements about assessing the personality of an individual is correct?

options.A: This involves giving short-term acquaintances questionnaires
options.B: The Minnesota multiphasic personality inventory is a poorly researched inventory
options.C: The best method is by observation made during an episode of illness
options.D: The trait approach is considered to be the most reliable method of assessment
options.E: The trait approach to personality assessment is the basis for the ICD-10 classification

explanation: The informants in personality assessments should have a good knowledge of the person for a number of years.

question: A mother of a 7-year-old boy kept giving him laxatives in his food covertly and frequently took him to the hospital and insisted on his admission. Which of the following statements about this situation is correct?

options.A: It is considered child maltreatment, according to definitions used by the government in England and Wales
options.B: Personality disorder is commonly observed among the perpetrators
options.C: The child won't be harmed because he is being cared for in hospital
options.D: This is best considered a form of parental psychopathology
options.E: This is exploitation of a vulnerable and defenceless child

explanation: The child is harmed directly or indirectly, leading to a variety of presentations.

question: According to current evidence, which of the following statements about the development of puberty compared with previous generations is correct?

options.A: Average age of menarche has reduced to below 11 years
options.B: One in four girls reaches puberty before the age of 8 years
options.C: One in ten 8-year-old boys has pubic hair
options.D: Puberty lasts longer than in previous generations
options.E: There is no change in the age of maturation of boys

explanation: The age of reaching puberty has decreased in the western population from 17 years to below 12–13 years. The average age of menarche in Britain is 12 years and 10 months. One in six girls reaches puberty before the age of 8 years and one in fourteen 8-year-old boys have pubic hair. Puberty starts earlier and lasts longer according to the children of the 1990s' study conducted by Bristol University's Institute of Child Health.

question: According to the New York longitudinal study, what percentage of the cohort was identified as having an easy temperament?
explanation: Thomas et al (1968) conducted a study of temperament in infants in the 1950s. Data was gathered initially by parental interviews that looked at nine traits that were combined to describe three temperament types. Easy temperament was identified in 40% of the cohort.

question: Which of the following statements about authoritarian parenting is correct?

options.D: Parents are willing to discuss with children

explanation: There are three main parenting styles described. An authoritarian parenting style is where parents do not negotiate and are strict. The boundaries set are clear and rigid.

question: A girl was placed in a day care at the age of 6 months when her mother returned to part-time work of 24 hours a week. According to Bowlby, what is the most likely effect on her around her first birthday?

options.E: Child's response in strange situation test shows a disorganised attachment

explanation: According to Bowlby, if a child before the age of 1 year is separated from the mother when she is working, maternal deprivation is likely to occur.

question: The adult attachment interview is a tool used in research. Which of the following statements is correct about this tool?

options.A: Five possible attachment styles can be identified
options.B: It identifies attachment relationships during adulthood
options.D: Studies use it in the context of intergenerational transfer of attachment patterns
options.E: It is used mainly to identify the individual who might have been sexually abused as a child

explanation: The adult attachment interview is a structured interview that explores an individual's experience of attachment relationships in childhood. Studies mainly use it in the context of intergenerational transfer of attachment patterns.

question: Which of the following statements about object relations theory is correct?

options.B: Only external object relations can be achieved
options.C: The work was lead primarily by Sigmund Freud
options.D: The paranoid–depressive positions are never fully resolved in adult life
options.E: It uses defence mechanisms such as sexualisation and idealisation

explanation: The work with regard to paranoid and depressive positions was led primarily by Melanie Klein. In this case, an infant divides the caregiver into an external object that is all good or an internal object that is all bad.

question: Who described the 'good-enough mother'?
explanation: Winnicot proposed the concept of the 'good-enough mother' who needs to be responsive but not extreme, to ensure adequate emotional development in the infant.

question: Which of the following statements about condensation in dream analysis is correct?

options.A: Dream content substitutes the target of one's feelings onto another person or object
options.C: It makes sense of the manifest content
options.D: It refers to what we dream about and are aware of on waking
options.E: More than one dream idea is combined into a single mental image

explanation: Condensation is more than one dream's idea combined into a single mental image.

question: Which of the following statements is about neurotic symptoms in psychoanalysis?

options.A: They are considered by Freud to be the 'secret road to the unconscious'
options.B: Dreams have different meanings from neurotic symptoms
options.C: The symptoms may symbolise the wish with which they are linked

explanation: Neurotic symptoms are viewed as similar to dreams. The symptoms are felt to be the expression of an unconscious and may symbolise the wish to which it is linked.

question: Which of the following describes snags in cognitive–analytical therapy?

options.B: Appropriate roles or goals abandoned because they are perceived as forbidden or dangerous.
options.C: Available action or possible roles limited to polarised alternatives
options.D: Negative assumptions which generate acts that reinforce the assumptions
options.E: Patient helped to recognise recurrences of unrevised patterns

explanation: Snags occur when the appropriate roles or goals are abandoned because the individual makes an assumption that others would oppose, or because they are perceived as forbidden or dangerous.

question: A 32-year-old man was reprimanded by his boss, although he did not react at the time. When he went home, he shouted at his wife and slapped her after a minor argument. What is the likely defence mechanism?
explanation: Displacement is shifting of the emotion from the real target onto a substitute.

question: According to jungian psychoanalysis, which of the following statements refers to consciousness?

options.D: It is made up of the individual's unique experiences involving repression
options.E: It includes the mind's inherited characteristics that influence the reactions

explanation: According to Jung there are three levels that make up the psyche such as consciousness, personal unconscious and collective unconscious. The consciousness has four basic functions, namely thinking, feeling, sensing and intuiting.

question: In Yalom's universal therapeutic factors, catharsis refers to which of the following?

options.A: Expression of affect in a supportive environment
options.B: Filled with therapeutic optimism by seeing others improve
options.C: Improving one's self-esteem by helping another
options.D: Model helpful behaviours of other members
options.E: Recognition of common experiences and that it reflects experiences in wider society

explanation: Catharsis is when the individual feels unburdened difficult emotions, by expressing affect in a supportive environment.

question: Which of the following statements best describes the technique of paradoxical injunction used in systemic family therapy?

options.A: Different positions are assigned to parts of the family structure
options.B: Members of the family are 'prescribed' their symptom which can paradoxically lead to an alteration
options.C: Practical solutions are developed between family members
options.D: Tasks are assigned to family members to complete between sessions, which involve a change in their actions to see how it affects the system
options.E: Thought is given to how to live with symptoms if they cannot be altered

explanation: Members of the family are 'prescribed' their symptom which can paradoxically lead to an alteration.

question: Which of the following therapies is the treatment of choice for anorexia nervosa in adolescents?
explanation: Systemic family therapy is the treatment of choice for adolescents with anorexia nervosa and is particularly effective with early onset anorexia.

question: A 20-year-old woman recently diagnosed with moderate depression would prefer a psychological therapy rather than taking medication. Which of the following therapies should be recommended?
explanation: Cognitive–behavioural therapy (CBT) is recommended as a psychological intervention in depression.

question: A 26-year-old school teacher felt that she was responsible for every child in her class passing the examination, otherwise her colleagues would view her as a failure. Which of the following cognitive errors does she have?
explanation: Excessive responsibility is assuming personal responsibility for all negative outcomes.

question: Which of the following statements about dialectical behavioural therapy is correct?

options.A: It can extend for a maximum of 6 months
options.C: It involves exploring childhood adversity with a therapist through free association
options.E: The therapy is intensive with group and individual work

explanation: Dialectic behavioural therapy (DBT) is an integrative therapy developed by Marsha Linehan.

question: Which of the following is one of the stages of eye-movement desensitisation and reprocessing?
explanation: Target assessment is one of the stages of eye movement desensitisation and reprocessing (EMDR).

question: Which of the following statements about the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence's guideline for a stepped care approach to generalised anxiety disorder is correct?

options.C: Step 3 – day hospital or inpatient care can be considered
options.D: Step 4 – considered if there is high risk of self-harm
options.E: Step 5 – CBT or drug treatment can be initiated

explanation: Step 4 is considered if there is high risk of self-harm, self-neglect, failed step 3 or complex GAD condition.

question: Which of the following statements about psychological treatments for people with an antisocial personality disorder (ASPD) is correct?

options.A: Most of the psychological interventions delivered in the criminal justice system are largely based on concepts of conditioning
options.B: Psychological interventions for almost all of the components of ASPD are well developed
options.C: Roughly half of all interventions delivered in the criminal justice system are aimed at reducing offending behaviour
options.D: There has been significant formal development of psychological interventions for ASPD
options.E: There is a good research base for psychological management for comorbid disorders seen in ASPD

explanation: There is a good research base for psychological management for comorbid disorders seen in ASPD.

question: Which of the following statements about combined CBT and antidepressants is correct?

options.A: After ending treatment, relapse rates of depression are similar in those treated with either CBT or antidepressants
options.B: CBT is as effective as antidepressant medication in depressed inpatients
options.C: Drug treatments have a higher relapse rate than CBT on discontinuation in generalised anxiety disorder
options.D: The combination of CBT and antidepressant medication may be as effective as either alone in severe depression
options.E: The combination of CBT and medication in mild-to-moderate depression is more effective than either alone

explanation: Drug treatments have a higher relapse rate than CBT on discontinuation in generalised anxiety disorder.

question: Which of the following treatments is harmful in post-traumatic stress disorder?
explanation: The National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guidance does not recommend debriefing as it can be more harmful.

question: A 44-year-old woman complained of intense and irrational fears about eating in front of other people. Her therapist arranged a session at which she consumed a meal in front of four strangers. During the session, they looked at her but did not talk to her. However, she occasionally observed them whispering to each other. What type of therapy has been described?
explanation: Flooding occurs in vivo and is also known as implosion, where the therapist exposes the patient to a controlled environment to evoke anxiety.

question: Which of the following is an inclusion criterion for group therapy?

options.C: Problem areas incompatible with group goals
options.D: Severe incompatibility with one or more group members

explanation: Motivation to change is an inclusion criterion for group therapy.

question: A 20-year-old female college student repeatedly self-harmed, expressed feelings of being miserable, lonely and abandoned by family and friends. She found it difficult to maintain romantic relationships. Which of the following is the most appropriate psychological therapy for treatment?
explanation: Dialectical behavioural therapy (DBT) is the most appropriate psychological therapy for individuals with borderline personality disorder.

question: Which of the following statements is consistent with emotional deprivation in children?

options.A: A child will show either clinging or detachment after short-term deprivation
options.B: After long-term deprivation children become self-sufficient through detachment
options.C: Long-term deprivation includes a child going to stay with grandparents, while the mother is on holiday
options.D: Short-term deprivation includes separation after a divorce
options.E: There are no long-term effects of short-term deprivation in children

explanation: After long-term deprivation, children may become self-sufficient through detachment.

question: Which of the following is a risk factor related to the parent/environment for child abuse?

options.B: Good socioeconomic status and high-powered job of parents

explanation: Risk characteristics of parents who abuse children include being a single parent, young age, abused themselves as a child, low self-esteem, unrealistic expectations of the child's development, and inconsistent or punishment-oriented discipline.

question: Which of the following statements about couples and divorce in the UK is correct?

options.A: About 60% of couples cohabit before they marry
options.B: After divorce, men have a lower rate of remarriage than women
options.C: Couples who cohabit before marriage are unlikely to divorce later
options.D: Divorce rates peak after 10–12 years of marriage
options.E: Divorce rates are highest in individuals in late 30s

explanation: About 60% of couples cohabit before they marry.

question: Which of the following vulnerability factors in parents is considered in identifying children at risk of developing conduct problems?

options.A: All mothers are younger than 18 years
options.B: At least one of the parents is on social security benefits
options.C: At least one parent has a degree of contact with the criminal justice system
options.D: Parents have an education status below the GCSE level
options.E: Parents have other mental health problems

explanation: The presence of the following vulnerability factors in parents can be useful in identifying children at risk of developing conduct problems: Parents with other mental health problems.

question: Which of the following statements about association between sexual abuse and psychiatric disorder is correct?

options.A: Girls are more prone to psychiatric disorders than boys after sexual abuse
options.B: A history of rape does not add any more to the risks of a psychiatric disorder if sexual abuse had already occurred
options.C: Patients are more prone to psychiatric disorders when they were abused before the age of 10 years compared with after the age of 15 years
options.D: There is enough evidence to show an association between sexual abuse and obsessive–compulsive disorder
options.E: There is a statistically significant association between sexual abuse and lifetime diagnosis of sleep disorders

explanation: There is a statistically significant association between sexual abuse and lifetime diagnosis of sleep disorders.
